title: How to Tile a Wall With Porcelain Tile

steps.headline: Prepare the area around your walls.
steps.description: Place drop cloths on the floor to catch dust and tile pieces.

steps.headline: Wear protective clothing.
steps.description: You should use safety goggles, long shirts, long pants and gloves. Broken tile can be sharp and dangerous.

steps.headline: Remove the old tile, if necessary.
steps.description: It is inadvisable to try to tile over old tile, because your surface will not be even. Use a chisel and a hammer to crack existing tiles. Once cracked, remove the tile in pieces, if it does not fall off automatically. Chisel off remaining pieces. Beware not to gouge the wall too deeply, or you may create an uneven surface. If the resulting wall is very uneven, you may want to re-plaster it. It is best to hire a professional to plaster the walls. If you are installing wall tile in a bathroom or other wet area, use cement fiberboard on the surface before you adhere tile.

steps.headline: Sand the wall with medium-grit sandpaper to create an even surface.
steps.description: If you are not removing previous tile, you will still want to scuff up glossy surfaces with a fine-grit sandpaper to help the adhesive stick.

steps.headline: Buy your tiles.
steps.description: Porcelain tiles are available through the Internet, home improvement stores and decorators. Buy extra tile for your project, since tiles will break in the process. Take your tile to the home improvement store to try out glue. Different ceramic tiles require different types of glue. You do not want your glue to discolor the tile.

steps.headline: Apply a wall sealant.
steps.description: This mild adhesive product will keep the glue moist while you complete your project. It is available at home improvement stores.

steps.headline: Measure the size of the tiles you want to use and any tile spacers or grout.
steps.description: Decide how many tiles you will need to use to complete your pattern.

steps.headline: Ensure level tiles with the use of a batten, or wooden straight edge.
steps.description: Do not measure the tile according to the ceiling or floor, since these surfaces are not always level. Place a batten horizontally across the wall, and use a level to make it straight.

steps.headline: Pin the batten on the wall.
steps.description: Mark where the tiles will go with a pencil, including spacers or grout. The batten will help you to keep the tile straight and evenly spaced, so do not avoid this time-consuming step.

steps.headline: Use a vertical batten for your first tiles as well.
steps.description: Pin a level vertical batten in place. This will ensure your first tiles are at a 90 degree angle.

steps.headline: Apply a layer of glue to the area above the batten with a notched trowel.
steps.description: You can use a vertical straight edge to help align the tile uniformly. In small areas, you may need to apply the glue with a brush, but make sure it has a notched surface.

steps.headline: Place a tile spacer between the tiles as you set them into the glue to allow space for grout.
Press the tile into the wall with a wooden board.
steps.description: Allow the tiles to dry according to adhesive directions in small areas, so that you can concentrate on making the tiles straight.

steps.headline: Wipe away any excess glue with a wall scraper.
steps.description: Then, wipe away the tops of the tiles with a wet rag.

steps.headline: Cut porcelain tiles to go near the edges of your walls.
steps.description: You will need to use a wet cutter with a blade that goes in water. Measure each tile before cutting for a good fit.

steps.headline: Allow the tiles to dry for at least 24 to 36 hours.
steps.description: The glue directions should specify the necessary time.

steps.headline: Spread grout over the surface of the tile with a grout float.
steps.description: Choose a tile that is water and mold resistant.

steps.headline: Clean the surface of the tile with a wet sponge.
steps.description: Run the wet sponge over the surface of the tile. Allow the grout to dry completely.

steps.headline: Polish the surface of your tiles with a dry cotton rag.
steps.description: This should remove any remaining grout residue.
